lines.text: Flourish. Enter KING, COUNTESS, LAFEU, the two French Lords, with Attendants

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: We lost a jewel of her and our esteem Was made much poorer by it: but your son, As mad in folly, lackd the sense to know Her estimation home.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Tis past, my liege And I beseech your majesty to make it Natural rebellion, done i the blaze of youth When oil and fire, too strong for reasons force, Oerbears it and burns on.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: My honourd lady, I have forgiven and forgotten all Though my revenges were high bent upon him, And watchd the time to shoot.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: This I must say, But first I beg my pardon, the young lord Did to his majesty, his mother and his lady Offence of mighty note but to himself The greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife Whose beauty did astonish the survey Of richest eyes, whose words all ears took captive, Whose dear perfection hearts that scornd to serve Humbly calld mistress.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Praising what is lost Makes the remembrance dear. Well, call him hither We are reconciled, and the first view shall kill All repetition: let him not ask our pardon The nature of his great offence is dead, And deeper than oblivion we do bury The incensing relics of it: let him approach, A stranger, no offender and inform him So tis our will he should.

lines.speaker: gentleman
lines.text: I shall, my liege.
Exit

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: What says he to your daughter have you spoke

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: All that he is hath reference to your highness.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Then shall we have a match. I have letters sent me That set him high in fame.
Enter BERTRAM

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: He looks well ont.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: I am not a day of season, For thou mayst see a sunshine and a hail In me at once: but to the brightest beams Distracted clouds give way so stand thou forth The time is fair again.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: My highrepented blames, Dear sovereign, pardon to me.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: All is whole Not one word more of the consumed time. Lets take the instant by the forward top For we are old, and on our quickst decrees The inaudible and noiseless foot of Time Steals ere we can effect them. You remember The daughter of this lord

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Admiringly, my liege, at first I stuck my choice upon her, ere my heart Durst make too bold a herald of my tongue Where the impression of mine eye infixing, Contempt his scornful perspective did lend me, Which warpd the line of every other favour Scornd a fair colour, or expressd it stolen Extended or contracted all proportions To a most hideous object: thence it came That she whom all men praised and whom myself, Since I have lost, have loved, was in mine eye The dust that did offend it.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Well excused: That thou didst love her, strikes some scores away From the great compt: but love that comes too late, Like a remorseful pardon slowly carried, To the great sender turns a sour offence, Crying, Thats good thats gone. Our rash faults Make trivial price of serious things we have, Not knowing them until we know their grave: Oft our displeasures, to ourselves unjust, Destroy our friends and after weep their dust Our own love waking cries to see whats done, While shame full late sleeps out the afternoon. Be this sweet Helens knell, and now forget her. Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin: The main consents are had and here well stay To see our widowers second marriageday.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Which better than the first, O dear heaven, bless! Or, ere they meet, in me, O nature, cesse!

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Come on, my son, in whom my houses name Must be digested, give a favour from you To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter, That she may quickly come. By my old beard, And every hair thats ont, Helen, thats dead, Was a sweet creature: such a ring as this, The last that eer I took her at court, I saw upon her finger.
BERTRAM gives a ring

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Hers it was not.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Now, pray you, let me see it for mine eye, While I was speaking, oft was fastend tot. This ring was mine and, when I gave it Helen, I bade her, if her fortunes ever stood Necessitied to help, that by this token I would relieve her. Had you that craft, to reave her Of what should stead her most

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: My gracious sovereign, Howeer it pleases you to take it so, The ring was never hers.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Son, on my life, I have seen her wear it and she reckond it At her lifes rate.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: I am sure I saw her wear it.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: You are deceived, my lord she never saw it: In Florence was it from a casement thrown me, Wrappd in a paper, which containd the name Of her that threw it: noble she was, and thought I stood engaged: but when I had subscribed To mine own fortune and informd her fully I could not answer in that course of honour As she had made the overture, she ceased In heavy satisfaction and would never Receive the ring again.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Plutus himself, That knows the tinct and multiplying medicine, Hath not in natures mystery more science Than I have in this ring: twas mine, twas Helens, Whoever gave it you. Then, if you know That you are well acquainted with yourself, Confess twas hers, and by what rough enforcement You got it from her: she calld the saints to surety That she would never put it from her finger, Unless she gave it to yourself in bed, Where you have never come, or sent it us Upon her great disaster.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: She never saw it.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Thou speakst it falsely, as I love mine honour And makest conjectural fears to come into me Which I would fain shut out. If it should prove That thou art so inhuman,twill not prove so And yet I know not: thou didst hate her deadly, And she is dead which nothing, but to close Her eyes myself, could win me to believe, More than to see this ring. Take him away. My forepast proofs, howeer the matter fall, Shall tax my fears of little vanity, Having vainly feard too little. Away with him! Well sift this matter further.
Guards seize BERTRAM

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: If you shall prove This ring was ever hers, you shall as easy Prove that I husbanded her bed in Florence, Where yet she never was.
Exit, guarded

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: I am wrappd in dismal thinkings.
Enter a Gentleman

lines.speaker: gentleman
lines.text: Gracious sovereign, Whether I have been to blame or no, I know not: Heres a petition from a Florentine, Who hath for four or five removes come short To tender it herself. I undertook it, Vanquishd thereto by the fair grace and speech Of the poor suppliant, who by this I know Is here attending: her business looks in her With an importing visage and she told me, In a sweet verbal brief, it did concern Your highness with herself.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: [Reads]  Upon his many protestations to marry me when his wife was dead, I blush to say it, he won me. Now is the Count Rousillon a widower: his vows are forfeited to me, and my honours paid to him. He stole from Florence, taking no leave, and I follow him to his country for justice: grant it me, O king! in you it best lies otherwise a seducer flourishes, and a poor maid is undone. DIANA CAPILET.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: I will buy me a soninlaw in a fair, and toll for this: Ill none of him.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: The heavens have thought well on thee Lafeu, To bring forth this discovery. Seek these suitors: Go speedily and bring again the count. I am afeard the life of Helen, lady, Was foully snatchd.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Now, justice on the doers!
Reenter BERTRAM, guarded

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: I wonder, sir, sith wives are monsters to you, And that you fly them as you swear them lordship, Yet you desire to marry. What womans that
Enter Widow and DIANA

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: I am, my lord, a wretched Florentine, Derived from the ancient Capilet: My suit, as I do understand, you know, And therefore know how far I may be pitied.

lines.speaker: widow
lines.text: I am her mother, sir, whose age and honour Both suffer under this complaint we bring, And both shall cease, without your remedy.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Come hither, count do you know these women

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: My lord, I neither can nor will deny But that I know them: do they charge me further

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Why do you look so strange upon your wife

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Shes none of mine, my lord.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: If you shall marry, You give away this hand, and that is mine You give away heavens vows, and those are mine You give away myself, which is known mine For I by vow am so embodied yours, That she which marries you must marry me, Either both or none.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Your reputation comes too short for my daughter you are no husband for her.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: My lord, this is a fond and desperate creature, Whom sometime I have laughd with: let your highness Lay a more noble thought upon mine honour Than for to think that I would sink it here.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Sir, for my thoughts, you have them ill to friend Till your deeds gain them: fairer prove your honour Than in my thought it lies.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Good my lord, Ask him upon his oath, if he does think He had not my virginity.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: What sayst thou to her

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Shes impudent, my lord, And was a common gamester to the camp.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: He does me wrong, my lord if I were so, He might have bought me at a common price: Do not believe him. O, behold this ring, Whose high respect and rich validity Did lack a parallel yet for all that He gave it to a commoner o the camp, If I be one.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: He blushes, and tis it: Of six preceding ancestors, that gem, Conferrd by testament to the sequent issue, Hath it been owed and worn. This is his wife That rings a thousand proofs.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Methought you said You saw one here in court could witness it.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: I did, my lord, but loath am to produce So bad an instrument: his names Parolles.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: I saw the man today, if man he be.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Find him, and bring him hither.
Exit an Attendant

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: What of him Hes quoted for a most perfidious slave, With all the spots o the world taxd and deboshd Whose nature sickens but to speak a truth. Am I or that or this for what hell utter, That will speak any thing

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: She hath that ring of yours.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: I think she has: certain it is I liked her, And boarded her i the wanton way of youth: She knew her distance and did angle for me, Madding my eagerness with her restraint, As all impediments in fancys course Are motives of more fancy and, in fine, Her infinite cunning, with her modern grace, Subdued me to her rate: she got the ring And I had that which any inferior might At marketprice have bought.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: I must be patient: You, that have turnd off a first so noble wife, May justly diet me. I pray you yet Since you lack virtue, I will lose a husband Send for your ring, I will return it home, And give me mine again.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: I have it not.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: What ring was yours, I pray you

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Sir, much like The same upon your finger.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Know you this ring this ring was his of late.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: And this was it I gave him, being abed.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: The story then goes false, you threw it him Out of a casement.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: I have spoke the truth.
Enter PAROLLES

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: My lord, I do confess the ring was hers.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: You boggle shrewdly, every feather stars you. Is this the man you speak of

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Ay, my lord.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Tell me, sirrah, but tell me true, I charge you, Not fearing the displeasure of your master, Which on your just proceeding Ill keep off, By him and by this woman here what know you

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: So please your majesty, my master hath been an honourable gentleman: tricks he hath had in him, which gentlemen have.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Come, come, to the purpose: did he love this woman

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Faith, sir, he did love her but how

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: How, I pray you

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: He did love her, sir, as a gentleman loves a woman.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: How is that

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: He loved her, sir, and loved her not.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: As thou art a knave, and no knave. What an equivocal companion is this!

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I am a poor man, and at your majestys command.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Hes a good drum, my lord, but a naughty orator.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Do you know he promised me marriage

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Faith, I know more than Ill speak.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: But wilt thou not speak all thou knowest

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Yes, so please your majesty. I did go between them, as I said but more than that, he loved her: for indeed he was mad for her, and talked of Satan and of Limbo and of Furies and I know not what: yet I was in that credit with them at that time that I knew of their going to bed, and of other motions, as promising her marriage, and things which would derive me ill will to speak of therefore I will not speak what I know.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Thou hast spoken all already, unless thou canst say they are married: but thou art too fine in thy evidence therefore stand aside. This ring, you say, was yours

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Ay, my good lord.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Where did you buy it or who gave it you

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: It was not given me, nor I did not buy it.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Who lent it you

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: It was not lent me neither.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Where did you find it, then

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: I found it not.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: If it were yours by none of all these ways, How could you give it him

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: I never gave it him.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: This womans an easy glove, my lord she goes off and on at pleasure.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: This ring was mine I gave it his first wife.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: It might be yours or hers, for aught I know.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Take her away I do not like her now To prison with her: and away with him. Unless thou tellst me where thou hadst this ring, Thou diest within this hour.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Ill never tell you.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Take her away.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Ill put in bail, my liege.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: I think thee now some common customer.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: By Jove, if ever I knew man, twas you.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Wherefore hast thou accused him all this while

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Because hes guilty, and he is not guilty: He knows I am no maid, and hell swear tot Ill swear I am a maid, and he knows not. Great king, I am no strumpet, by my life I am either maid, or else this old mans wife.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: She does abuse our ears: to prison with her.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Good mother, fetch my bail. Stay, royal sir: The jeweller that owes the ring is sent for, And he shall surety me. But for this lord, Who hath abused me, as he knows himself, Though yet he never harmd me, here I quit him: He knows himself my bed he hath defiled And at that time he got his wife with child: Dead though she be, she feels her young one kick: So theres my riddle: one thats dead is quick: And now behold the meaning.
Exit Widow
Reenter Widow, with HELENA

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Is there no exorcist Beguiles the truer office of mine eyes Ist real that I see

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: No, my good lord Tis but the shadow of a wife you see, The name and not the thing.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Both, both. O, pardon!

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: O my good lord, when I was like this maid, I found you wondrous kind. There is your ring And, look you, heres your letter this it says: When from my finger you can get this ring And are by me with child,  and c. This is done: Will you be mine, now you are doubly won

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: If she, my liege, can make me know this clearly, Ill love her dearly, ever, ever dearly.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: If it appear not plain and prove untrue, Deadly divorce step between me and you! O my dear mother, do I see you living

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Mine eyes smell onions I shall weep anon: Good Tom Drum, lend me a handkercher: so, I thank thee: wait on me home, Ill make sport with thee: Let thy courtesies alone, they are scurvy ones.
To PAROLLES

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Let us from point to point this story know, To make the even truth in pleasure flow. If thou best yet a fresh uncropped flower, Choose thou thy husband, and Ill pay thy dower For I can guess that by thy honest aid Thou keepst a wife herself, thyself a maid. Of that and all the progress, more or less, Resolvedly more leisure shall express: All yet seems well and if it end so meet, The bitter past, more welcome is the sweet. EPILOGUE The kings a beggar, now the play is done: All is well ended, if this suit be won, That you express content which we will pay, With strife to please you, day exceeding day: Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts.
To DIANA
Flourish
Exeunt
